headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Flavors & Fragrances Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Michael DeVeau, Vice President, Global Corporate Com
componenttext: At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Flavors & Fragrances Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to introduce Michael DeVeau, Vice President, Global Corporate Communications and Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, good afternoon and good evening, everyone. Welcome to IFF's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Conference Call. Yesterday evening, we distributed a press release announcing our financial results. A copy of the release can be found
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, good afternoon and good evening, everyone. Welcome to IFF's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Conference Call. Yesterday evening, we distributed a press release announcing our financial results. A copy of the release can be found in our IR website. 
Please note that this call is being recorded live and will be available for replay on our website. Please take a moment to review our forward-looking statements. During the call, we will be making forward-looking statements about the company's performance, particularly with regard to our outlook to the first quarter and full year 2016. These statements are based on how we see things today and contain elements of uncertainty. For additional information concerning the factors that can cause actual results to differ materially from forward-looking statements, please refer to our cautionary statement and risk factors contained in our 10-K. Today's presentation will include non-GAAP financial measures, which exclude those items that we believe affect comparability. A reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to their respective GAAP measures is set forth in our press release. 
With me on the call today is our Chairman and CEO, Andreas Fibig; and our Executive Vice President and CFO, Alison Cornell. We will start the call with prepared remarks and then take any questions that you may have. 
With that, I would now like to introduce Andreas.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Michael. I would like to start with my executive overview of our operational performance for the full year. And I want to provide an update on the progress we are making in terms of our long-term 2020 strategy. Once finished, I will ask Alison
componenttext:
Thank you, Michael. I would like to start with my executive overview of our operational performance for the full year. And I want to provide an update on the progress we are making in terms of our long-term 2020 strategy. Once finished, I will ask Alison to cover our financial results in greater detail, including a comprehensive review of our fourth quarter, cash flow statement and cash return to shareholders. Then we will both provide commentary as it relates to our outlook for 2016 and finish by taking any questions that you may have. 
Starting with the financial review of our consolidated results for the full year 2015. I'm pleased to report that currency neutral sales grew 5%, which encompasses 6% growth in Flavors and 4% growth in Fragrances. Overall, topline growth benefited from a 2 percentage point contribution from the acquisition of Ottens Flavors and Lucas Meyer Cosmetics. In addition, our organic business, which grew 3% on a currency neutral base, continued to benefit from strong new win performance, particularly in Fragrance Compounds, as sales related to new wins finished above our 5-year average. 
For the full year 2015 and on a currency neutral basis, consolidated adjusted operating profit increased 8% and adjusted operating profit margin expanded by 50 basis points. As a result of our sales growth, the benefit associated with cost savings and productivity initiatives, mixed gains related to acquisitions and lower incentive compensation expense. This improvement in operating profit, when combined, was a more favorable effective tax rate and the reduction in shares outstanding led to a 11% increase in our currency neutral adjusted EPS in 2015. 
While I'm pleased with our results on a full-year base, I'm not satisfied with our top line performance in the fourth quarter. That is driven by a combination of a challenging year-over-year comparison due to an additional week of sales or the 53rd week of 2014, a concentrated effort by some of our larger customers to manage inventories in advance of year end, the portfolio rationalization of one of our largest Fragrance Ingredients customers and increased economic pressure in key emerging markets such as China. 
We did not perform as well as we would have expected. Alison will go through the specifics in greater detail in a moment. Before doing so, I want to highlight the strategic progress we have made as it relates to our Vision 2020 strategy. 
Since the communication of our strategy in June 2, 2015, we have taken steps to deliver on our ambition to achieve target market leadership, defined by #1 or 2 market share positions in key markets, capital risk and customers. Within the emerging markets, we've identified the Middle East and Africa as an area of focus, given the robust economic trends and the impact on our consumer disposable income in the future. I'm happy to report, even as we are very early in our journey, that for the full year, Middle East and Africa were up 14% on a currency neutral basis. 
Similarly with Fragrance Compounds, China grew high single digits as the local teams continue to leverage our long-standing presence and in-depth consumer knowledge to win both global and regional customers. 
Consumer Fragrances continued its mid to high single-digit growth trend in 2015. And within that segment, Home Care, an area of focus for us, grew high single digits for the full-year on a currency neutral basis, led by double-digit growth in Latin America. 
In Flavors Latin America, we delivered 16% currently neutral sales growth, driven in part by key customers and our proprietary delivery systems. In 2015, North America, we believe, we are now the #2 flavors company with our acquisition of Ottens Flavors, which will be adding approximately $60 million in annual sales to our business. 
Over the course of the year, we also made strong progress against our innovating first pillar, as we believe our robust technology pipeline is critical to building greater differentiation and ultimately accelerated growth. In quarter 4, we commercialized 2 additional capital Fragrance Ingredients molecules, bringing our total output to 4 in 2015. In addition, the cost of fruit and Crystal Fizz, which I spoke about last quarter, in quarter 4, we commercialized [indiscernible] and [indiscernible], both molecules are strong performers in all applications and give our perfumers a competitive edge when creating the next great fragrance for our customers. 
We are proud of these accomplishments as we set up annual fragrance ingredient molecules output average. We believe this is very critical in terms of differentiation and it provides us with greater confidence in our growth and visions going forward. 
The strong trends in Fabric Care and Beverage continued in the fourth quarter, driven by our industry-leading encapsulation technology in Fragrances and proprietary delivery system in Flavors. The growth trend of encapsulation-related sales continued in 2015 as currency neutral sales improved mid-teens led by Fabric Care and Home Care. 
For the full year 2015, Fabric Care grew high single digits on a currency neutral basis, with all geographic markets posting strong growth, led by double-digit growth in EAME and Latin America. Leveraging our success in Fabric Care, we developed a new capsule in 2015, which will allow us to extend this critical encapsulation technology into Personal Care category such as Hair Care and Body Wash. 
Sales of our Sweetness and Savory Modulation portfolio continued to produce strong results, increasing double digits in 2015. The categories where we had the most success were savory, Dairy and Beverage as our innovative solutions are allowing our customers to meet the demands of consumers while primarily looking to reduce sugar and salt. 
Building on the strengths, we also commercialized 2 natural pace modulators in 2015. The addition of these modulators will further strengthen our capabilities and it provides our flavors a more competitive element for which to build winning solutions for our customers. 
In addition to the strides we have made from a market share and innovation perspective, we've also made a progress in our never-ending quest to become our customers' partner of choice. In December, we launch our refreshed branding where we unveiled the new website, service statement, visual identity and tone of voice, all of which are geared towards showcasing IFF's vision imagination and innovative focus to customers, employees and, of course, shareholders. 
I'm proud of the recognition we have received from our customers in 2015. Over the course of the year, we won the North American Innovation Award with one of the largest flavors customers which recognizes partners for their [indiscernible] leadership. In addition, Estée Lauder presented us with their Suppliers Excellence Award, an achievement designed to acknowledge their top-performing business partners. Also, Lucas Meyer Cosmetics, which we acquired in August, over 2015 in Cosmetics Asia Gold award for best active ingredient innovation and best functional ingredient. More recently, they also received first prize of the first Cosmetic Ingredients Show of 2016. 
When it comes sustainability, at IFF, we will not accept the status quo. We believe this is foundational to our Vision 2020 business strategy, which is why we are committed to embedding sustainability throughout our business practices and our corporate culture. As you can see on this slide, 2015 was a very successful year in terms of accomplishment. 
While the first 3 pillars focus on leveraging or improving our existing capabilities and infrastructure, the fourth pillar strengthening and extending the portfolio aims to support our organic business through M&A partnerships and collaboration. 
During the second and third quarter of 2015, we completed 2 acquisitions. One focusing on growing our market share in North America and one focusing on expanding into new adjacencies which are of strategic value. Both acquisitions in 2015 have performed well and are ahead of our business case in terms of sales growth and margin enhancement. We believe that performance is a good indication that they're allocating towards long-term value creating opportunities. Overall, I'm pleased with the progress we have made from a strategic perspective and I'm committed to continuing this momentum as we move through 2016. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Alison.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andreas. Giving the softness experienced in the fourth quarter, I want us to reconcile with what we communicated in our third quarter conference call to actual Q4 results. On November 11, we stated that we expect to have moderate currency neutr
componenttext:
Thank you, Andreas. Giving the softness experienced in the fourth quarter, I want us to reconcile with what we communicated in our third quarter conference call to actual Q4 results. On November 11, we stated that we expect to have moderate currency neutral sales growth in the fourth quarter with organic sales flat to down slightly in Q4. At that time, as shown in the chart, currency neutral sales on an organic basis was up 2% in October. As you move to November, our growth trajectory continued, with currency neutral sales up nearly 3% for the month. Then, unfortunately, our performance in December came in softer than we expected. While we knew we faced a strong year ago comparisons that included an extra week of sales, which we quantified to be 200 basis points in the quarter or approximately 600 basis points in the month of December, there were a few other factors that further pressured results. 
First, in Flavors, we experienced unprecedented fluctuations in terms of customer order patterns. While traditionally, we have good visibility around the commercialization of products, there were customers recurring order patterns, we ultimately are dependent on our customers in terms of launches and inventory levels. In December, we unexpectedly experienced several large Flavors customers reducing their overall order intake, which impacted results. This was also the case in Consumer Fragrances where customers did not reorder at the same level as they did in the year-ago period, excluding the 53rd week impact. 
In Fragrances, our Ingredients business remained under pressure, as one of our largest Fragrance Ingredients customers continued to rationalize their product portfolio. In Q4, the impact was even more pronounced, which further pressured results. 
And lastly, we continue to see pressure in Flavors in China, partly due to a weaker economic environment but also some lost business related to the manufacturing issues we faced earlier in the year. 
In light of our challenging currency neutral sales growth, we still managed to deliver strong adjusted EPS growth. In the quarter, acquisitions contributed approximately 4 percentage points to overall growth. 
There are 2 areas that I want to highlight in terms of our top line in the quarter. The first is Latin America Flavors where we continue to benefit from our industry-leading delivery system technology and take market share from our competition. Also in Latin America, Fine Fragrance has returned to growth in the fourth quarter and volume growth appears to be normalizing and we continue to win new business as we significantly outperformed the market. 
From a profit perspective, consolidated adjusted operating profit on a currency neutral basis increased 3% and adjusted operating profit margin expanded 40 basis points, escrows towards an expansion, the benefits of productivity initiatives, M&A and reduced incentive compensation drove results. Below the line, currency neutral adjusted EPS increased 9%, thanks in large part to a lower adjusted effective tax rate, down 210 basis points and an 830,000 share reduction in shares outstanding as a result of our share repurchase program. 
Despite this softer than expected sales and operating profit performance in Q4, we still delivered a solid financial performance on a full-year basis. Currency neutral sales improved 5%. Currency neutral adjusted operating profit grew 8%, and currency neutral adjusted EPS increased 11%. From a cash flow perspective, our core working capital levels continued to show improvement year-over-year as a percentage of sales as our 5-quarter rolling average figures through the end of Q4 was down 3 [ph] basis points, due approximately 28.7% of our 2015 annual sales. 
Much of our gains came from higher payables as a result of a concentrated effort to improve our days payables outstanding. On a full-year basis, our DPO increased by 9 days to 54 days, from 45 days a year ago. Operating cash flow from operations at the end of the fourth quarter was $434 million, including an incremental $24 million pension contribution. Excluding the incremental portion of the pension contribution, adjusted operating cash flow would have increased to $458 million or 15.2% of adjusted operating cash flow as a percentage of sales. Capital expenditures for the year finished at $101 million or approximately 3.3% of sales as we continue to make investments to support our growth initiatives, principally as we finished our plans in Turkey and Indonesia. 
CapEx in 2015 came in below original expectations as the timing of several underpayments will now occur in 2016. As a result, we expect 2016 CapEx will increase to around 5% of sales as we plan to make incremental investments for manufacturing in a new Flavors site in China and to improve our site in India. 
The cash return to shareholders, dividend payments in 2015 were $160 million. This is a direct result of a 20% increase in August as our intention was to provide a more competitive yield, approximately 2%, while simultaneously balancing our growth objectives. Supplementing our dividend and remaining flexible to pursue M&A opportunities, we spent $122 million in share buybacks. Over the course of the year, we've repurchased approximately 1.1 million shares and lowered our diluted shares outstanding to 80.4 million shares. While combining both dividends and share repurchases, we achieved a 66% total payout ratio for adjusted net income, exceeding our targeted range of 50% to 60% and significantly ahead of prior year. Looking ahead to 2016, we can reiterate our targeted total payout ratio range of 50% to 60%. 
With that, I would like to turn the call back over to Andreas.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alison. As we look ahead to 2016, I want to provide an assessment of our vantage point as we stand here today. Basically, there are 4 key themes that we believe are relevant when planning our financial goals for 2016. From an economic perspectiv
componenttext:
Thanks, Alison. As we look ahead to 2016, I want to provide an assessment of our vantage point as we stand here today. Basically, there are 4 key themes that we believe are relevant when planning our financial goals for 2016. 
From an economic perspective, there's a lot of solidity around the world. While the developed markets of the U.S. and Western Europe appear to improving slowly and the emerging markets, the volatility we experienced in the second half of 2015 continues. Large markets like China appear to be decelerating and Brazil continues to decline. These 2 markets account for approximately 15% of our total sales. 
With regard to multinational consumer product companies. Volume expectations seem to be muted as many organizations appear to be focused on improving margins while taking pricing actions. And emerging markets to protect profitability. Fortunately, regional players continue to exhibit stronger volume trends, whether it be in the U.S. or in the emerging markets. This economic uncertainty has led to sharp declines in hard commodities such as oil, which is beneficial in terms of cost. This large decline in petrochemical should help in terms of input cost. Also, we continue to see naturals such as vanilla and citrus remaining elevated. 
Finally, in terms of foreign exchange, the U.S. dollar continues to strengthen against world currencies. This continues to be a challenge for most multinational companies based in the U.S. both in terms of translation and transaction exposure. 
With all that as context, we are preparing ourselves for even more challenging conditions given the higher level of economic uncertainty and the more cautious volume outlook of consumer packaged goods companies. We expect 3.5 to 4.5 currency neutral sales growth including approximately a 1.5 percentage point contribution on the acquisitions of Ottens and Lucas Meyer. From an organic perspective, growth is expected to be largely driven by Consumer Fragrances as well as Latin America and EAME and Flavors. 
From an operating profit perspective, we expect to achieve 5% to 7% growth, inclusive of the contribution of M&A. This improvement should be a result of gross margin expansion and productivity initiatives that more than offset the resetting of our annual incentive compensation program and investments in our strategy 2020. Both of which, Alison will touch on a moment. 
Currency neutral EPS growth is expected to improve by 6.5% to 8.5%, led by a modestly lower effective tax rate and the continuation of our share repurchase program. Longer-term, we continue to believe that over the 2016, 2020 horizon, we can deliver our Vision 2020 financial targets. We believe our emphasis on building greater differentiation, specifically in R&D, should ultimately lead to higher growth rates in the years to come. 
And in light of the recent instability in the financial markets around the world, I want to take a moment to reemphasize that IFF is a diversified and competitively advantaged organization. Whether you analyze our portfolio by category, region or customer, the breadth and diversity of our portfolio is great and our innovative solutions are key components of consumer staple products that enjoy long-term growth stability. We believe that our management team, as well as all IFF employees are capable of executing on our strategy 2020 to deliver long-term value for our shareholders. 
As we communicated at our recent Investor Day, we continue to believe that we can deliver organic currency neutral growth turn targets of 4% to 6% growth, 7% to 9% operating profit growth and 10% EPS growth over the course of '16 to 2020. 
With that, I would like to ask Alison to provide some additional remarks on our profitability outlook and foreign exchange exposure.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given the many moving parts, I wanted to provide additional insights and transparency into our expected profitability goal for 2016. In the table, we anchored on full-year 2015 adjusted operating profit and built out a reconciliation to bridge the 2016 op
componenttext:
Given the many moving parts, I wanted to provide additional insights and transparency into our expected profitability goal for 2016. In the table, we anchored on full-year 2015 adjusted operating profit and built out a reconciliation to bridge the 2016 operating profit. 
Starting with the second bar, you will note that we expect approximately a 4.5 percentage point headwind related to the resetting of our annual incentive compensation program. For those of you who are not familiar, we at IFF are highly incentivized to deliver on our financial commitments. From time to time, there are variations in our incentive compensation that is based on our performance relative to our annual plan. If we achieve our full-year financial targets, which are comprised of currency neutral sales growth, gross margin as a percentage of sales and absolute level of operating profit and working capital as a percentage of sales, we will receive 100% of our designated payout. Should be we overperform or under perform our annual plan, our incentive compensation is adjusted higher or lower, respectively. 
Since in 2015 we underperformed on a few components of our plan, our payout was below 100%. Now as we reset our targets in 2016, we budget for 100% payout, which ultimately is the driver behind the year-over-year variance. 
In the third bar, we've identified incremental investments we're making in Vision 2020. These are critical strategic investments. For example, R&D, application and commercial, geared toward delivering our long-term strategic and financial objectives. As we communicated on our Investor Day, we committed to self fund our reinvestment opportunities. 
In the fourth bar, you can see that we are aggressively attacking our cost base to not only cover our incremental investments but also help to deliver on our short-term profitability objectives. In addition to our standard course and productivity initiatives, which includes the likes of formula optimization, procurement savings and manufacturing efficiencies, we identified incremental savings opportunities via our Fund the Journey program. During the fourth quarter, we established a series of initiatives that are expected to streamline our management structure, simplify decision-making and accountability, better leverage and align our capabilities across the organization and improve our global manufacturing and operations network. As a result, the company recorded a pretax charge of approximately $8 million to cover severance and related costs associated with expected termination, a portion of which are subject to consultation processes. 
The company expects to realize pretax savings of $7 million to $9 million when fully implemented in the second half of 2017, half of which is expected to be realized in 2016, which is included in our 2016 guidance. 
Separately, the company recorded a charge of approximately $7 million associated with the acceleration from 2016 to 2015 of contingent consideration payments from the Aromor acquisition that was treated by certain of the effect of positions noted above. Then, the combination of our operational performance inclusive of M&A is expected to deliver 4% to 7% currency neutral operating profit growth. 
We expect foreign exchange, which I will discuss in greater detail in a moment, will have a 5 percentage point impact, bring our reported operating profit to be flat to up 2% in 2016. 
Before concluding, I would like to provide some additional insight into our foreign exchange exposure. Although 51% of our sales are to the emerging markets, not all of these sales are denominated in local currency. For a variety of reasons, many of our sales transactions in the emerging markets occur either in U.S. dollars or other hard currencies or are indexed to hard currencies we had to price in local emerging market currencies. 
As you can see in this chart, of the 51% of our sales in 2015 that weren't in emerging markets, approximately 70% were denominated in U.S. dollars or other hard currencies, leaving only 30% that are denominated in American market currency. As a result, our foreign exchange exposure to emerging markets currencies is rather limited. This is important, especially as we continue to see the U.S. dollar strengthen versus most emerging market currency. 
Given that fact, it's clear that the key hard currencies have been most impact on our profitability. Starting with the top box, we look at our profitability exposure. As we progress into 2016, while the Indian rupee, Japanese yen, Thai baht and Australian dollar are presenting modest headwinds in terms of currency, the euro is clearly the largest driver. As you can see, the devaluation of the euro versus U.S. dollars is expected to represent approximately 4 out of our 5 percentage point headwind in 2016. While we are hedged approximately 75% at 1 14 in 2016, the impact on profitability is about 2.5 percentage points plus the year-over-year variance of a hedging benefit in 2016 versus 2015. 
To allow you to more accurately forecast the exchange rate volatility, I've included our 2015 exchange rate as well as our planning rate for 2016. We hope that by giving you these details, you have greater visibility into our currency exposure as you can calculate the percentage change in each specific currency and the multiple -- and multiply by the percentage of profit each currency represents. 
I'd now like to turn the call back over to Andreas for some concluding remarks.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: In summary, 2015 was a fantastic year for IFF. We were able to deliver solid financial performance while also implementing our new Vision 2020 strategy geared towards accelerating profitable growth, building greater differentiation and maximizing sharehol
componenttext:
In summary, 2015 was a fantastic year for IFF. We were able to deliver solid financial performance while also implementing our new Vision 2020 strategy geared towards accelerating profitable growth, building greater differentiation and maximizing shareholder value. Our focus now continues to be on the execution of our strategy. 
In addition, 2015, we integrated 2 acquisitions to strengthen and further prioritize our R&D initiatives, achieve our sustainability objectives, grow our talent and invigorated IFF's brand with the launch of our new purpose statement and expanding elements, all of which helps both our vision, imagination and innovative focus. 
Looking forward, we are committed to our long-term targets and continue to believe that over the '16, 2020 horizon, we can deliver strong financial results. And now 2016 is more challenging in terms of the operating environment, we believe we can deliver solid financial results while simultaneously reinvesting in our business. 
With that, I would now like to open up the call for questions.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Mark Astrachan with Stifel.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Mark Astrachan with Stifel.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask on cost savings. So is the plan still to have the previously announced cost savings of 1% to 2% of sales fully reinvested back in the business given what looked in the slide that Alison was walking through that there was a 2% benefit to EB
componenttext: I wanted to ask on cost savings. So is the plan still to have the previously announced cost savings of 1% to 2% of sales fully reinvested back in the business given what looked in the slide that Alison was walking through that there was a 2% benefit to EBIT growth embedded in 2016 guidance? Sort of in other words, does the benefit become a drag even in 2017? And then just more broadly, on the same topic, does the current macro environment, which is clearly worse than it was in June 2015 when those original savings were outlined, require more cost savings to grow in line with long-term targets today? .

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, thank you for the question. Let me start and then I hand over to Alison. First of all, what we have started to be, and here, you've seen it in the call in terms of pretty aggressive, let's say, savings targets to make sure that we have good cost bas
componenttext: Mark, thank you for the question. Let me start and then I hand over to Alison. First of all, what we have started to be, and here, you've seen it in the call in terms of pretty aggressive, let's say, savings targets to make sure that we have good cost base which will help us going forward and the years to come as well. And we will take part of it to reinvest in particular, in R&D, because we believe had to build differentiation and new molecules. And as I hopefully have shown you during the presentation that we have already some of the success in terms of our pipelines, just mentioning growing from 2 fragrance to 4 fragrance and new, patented molecules which will help us to grow our base over the years to come. I agree with you. The economic environment has worsened compared to let's say, 8 to 9 months ago and that's the reason why we are cautious in terms of our outlook as well because the volatility is just very, very high right now. Let me hand over to Alison.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Mark. In addition to what Andreas said, the other thing -- we are being very aggressive from a cost cutting perspective. And what you've seen on the bridge chart that we provided from 2015 to 2016 is one of the items that we need to cover is our bonus
componenttext: So, Mark. In addition to what Andreas said, the other thing -- we are being very aggressive from a cost cutting perspective. And what you've seen on the bridge chart that we provided from 2015 to 2016 is one of the items that we need to cover is our bonus reset back to 1x. And so the cost-cutting is not only to cover the Vision 2020 but also to cover our bonus reset. And so we only anticipate having that same issue as we move into 2017.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Michael Sison with KeyBanc.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Michael Sison with KeyBanc.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andreas, when you think about 2016 and what you're hearing from your customers, is the slowdown in terms of demand coming from last -- new products starts, is it basically just customers, their customers not buying as much? Can you maybe touch on some of
componenttext: Andreas, when you think about 2016 and what you're hearing from your customers, is the slowdown in terms of demand coming from last -- new products starts, is it basically just customers, their customers not buying as much? Can you maybe touch on some of the underlying dynamics of what you're seeing in terms of the slowing in the markets?

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Mike, thank you for the question. It's probably a bit of a long-winded answer because a couple of pieces we have to piece together. So if we look, for example, to Fine Fragrance, we can say it's a good Christmas season. So we basically saw a good pe
componenttext: Okay, Mike, thank you for the question. It's probably a bit of a long-winded answer because a couple of pieces we have to piece together. So if we look, for example, to Fine Fragrance, we can say it's a good Christmas season. So we basically saw a good performance here. So we don't expect that we see a restocking effect here, so that's first part of the business. We've increase pipeline, project pipeline, particularly on the Fragrance Compounds side and also on the Flavors side so we see that this is good and very, very solid in Compounds. Fragrance, I would see it even for the average we've seen before. So that's good. On the Flavors side, we see that projects are happening and we have projects but not [indiscernible] executed for our customers and it depends how, let's say, how much they're selling them of the product. [indiscernible]side. On the geographic side, would we see is U.S. and Europe are actually pretty okay, coming back. We see a bit of the softness, in particular, in some of the emerging markets like China. And we should not forget that if we look at our customers in particular, the big CPG customers, that the outlook for volume is relatively muted. The good thing is, we don't see this with all of our regional and local customers. And as you know, our customers split is 50-50 with the big clients and the small one. So a bit of a long-winded answer. But there are really different different pieces to be looked at for 2016. I hope it helps.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Lauren Lieberman with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Lauren Lieberman with Barclays.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just following up on that. My sense is that the CPG customers that, at least over the last 6 months, I mean, your outlook certainly hasn't improved. But I don't really feel that there's been that much change in or out in terms of global market growth or v
componenttext: Just following up on that. My sense is that the CPG customers that, at least over the last 6 months, I mean, your outlook certainly hasn't improved. But I don't really feel that there's been that much change in or out in terms of global market growth or volume growth. Maybe that it's not getting better as quickly as you hope. But it certainly doesn't sound to me like it is worse. So I'm wondering if you're also seeing end market demand flow for those regional and local customers that the macro is now trickling into total market demand not just a bit of a share shift that you see happening. So that was my first question. The second was on the decision to invest in the new China Flavors facility. How does that tie into the existing manufacturing plant or I guess there's two. But the one that you had kind of the emissions issues in the summer. Can you just give us more color on that, that will be great. Thank you.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start probably with the Flavors first in China. We have made the decision that we are -- we will invest in the second plant. We plan to start groundbreaking at the end of the year and that will deliver us with, let's say, a backup plan for China fo
componenttext: Let me start probably with the Flavors first in China. We have made the decision that we are -- we will invest in the second plant. We plan to start groundbreaking at the end of the year and that will deliver us with, let's say, a backup plan for China for a market where we still believe we have to be present with a second plant for the [indiscernible]. So that's actually on track. On our existing Flavors spend, we had, earlier last year, we had the [indiscernible], older issue and it have sorted so far on the Flavors side. So that's working. We're back with our manufacturing of having settled that has cost us some business over the course of 2015. Coming back to your first question. What we see is a deceleration of order patterns with our global customers. And that's something which is certainly impacting the business. It depends certainly customer by customer and region by region so we really have to go into more of a detail. But still, for the smaller regional and local customers, it's -- the -- I would say, the assessment states that you have a couple of companies which have faster growth here. And it's actually good for us because we do significant business with these customers as well. I hope that helps.

componenttext: So from an -- I'd say from an attribution perspective, the 53rd week, we said in the quarter accounts for 200 basis points deterioration. And of that, there's 600 basis points associated with the month of December. And then, beyond that, in terms of timing of order patterns, that's about I'd say 1 percentage point. And then, I'd say the difference between the portfolio rationalization, well, China Flavors maybe [indiscernible] 1.2 and the difference is the portfolio rationalization. So those are the big chunks that we're trying to outline.

componenttext: So I have a couple of questions. The first question is, do you think you are losing share to some of your larger competitors? Because I know we talked about before, if you look at their organic growth, their definition is a little bit different than yours. But in talking to them, we've tried to quantify the difference and it seems like they're doing a lot better than you even on a two-year stack basis in various sort of, geographies and categories. And I'm particularly interested in China because they have been talking up China and telling investors that China's coming back and they're doing a lot better with the local regional players. So that indicates that you're looking shares. So I just wonder if you can shed some light on that and if you're concerned about that.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me start and then hand over to Alison. Fazia, thank you for the question. First of all, we don't believe that we are losing share. In contrary, we believe that we win share, particularly in some of the major categories, we are actually very, very s
componenttext: So let me start and then hand over to Alison. Fazia, thank you for the question. First of all, we don't believe that we are losing share. In contrary, we believe that we win share, particularly in some of the major categories, we are actually very, very strong. If we factor in the year ago comparison, so for the year, and we believe actually that going forward that this trend will continue. In particular, regarding China. We see a slowdown in the economy. But maybe Alison might comment on this one as well.

headline: International Flavors & Fragrances Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'd say it's probably 2 pieces from China. We see a deceleration of orders and we think that had to do with our order abatement issues that we experienced. But beyond that, our current pipeline is lower from a new breed perspective because we beli
componenttext: Yes, so I'd say it's probably 2 pieces from China. We see a deceleration of orders and we think that had to do with our order abatement issues that we experienced. But beyond that, our current pipeline is lower from a new breed perspective because we believe our clients are concerned a bit about not having a backup site in China and look for alternative suppliers in the short term. We believe once we've rectified that issue, there will be no issues from a volume perspective. But say, beyond that, I wanted to add to a variance comment about [indiscernible] and FX. Because the way that our clients or our competitors measure, they actually take the benefit of pricing in terms of their growth rate and so it's not really an apples-to-apples comparison as reported. And so you need to essentially stack the results down by maybe 1/3 to have an apples-to-apples comparison and then you take -- if you do that, you'll see on a full-year basis we're in fact performing better than our competition. The other distinction I wanted to make was when commenting in terms of China and share and brief, the comment is in particular to Flavors and not Fragrance because we are growing in the Fragrance space in China.
